content.text: The employee can't find your package. It's time to politely disagree and explain that you have a note (*een briefje*) saying it should be here.

data.tip: The '-je' ending makes a word a diminutive (smaller or cuter). It's pronounced like 'yuh'.

content.title: Questioning the Employee
content.setting: You're at the PostNL point. The employee has just told you they don't have your package.

conversation_flow.title: Receive bad news
conversation_flow.chatbot_message: Nee, ik heb het pakket niet.

conversation_flow.title: Say you have a note saying it's here
Show the note
conversation_flow.chatbot_message: Dank je. Ik kijk nog een keer...

content.text: They've looked again, but still no luck. Now you need to ask what to do next.

data.tip: This sound is made with rounded lips, like you're about to whistle. It's similar to the 'u' in the French word 'tu'.

content.text: To ask a yes/no question in Dutch, you often start with the verb. 'Het pakket komt' becomes 'Komt het pakket?'

content.title: Asking for a Solution
content.setting: The employee has checked again, but the package is nowhere to be found.

conversation_flow.title: Receive bad news again
conversation_flow.chatbot_message: Nee, het is hier echt niet.

content.text: You have a plan: come back tomorrow. It's time to end the conversation and leave.
The word `terug` means 'back'. It combines with a verb to show a return action: 'Ik kom terug' means 'I come back'.
`Graag gedaan` is the standard, polite reply when someone thanks you.

content.title: Ending the Conversation
content.setting: The employee has advised you to return tomorrow for your package.

conversation_flow.title: Thank the employee and say goodbye
